intro: Rubus chavinii, commonly known as Chavín blackberry, is a shrub native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its prickly stems and clusters of small, dark berries. The plant typically grows in rocky or mountainous habitats, preferring well-drained soils. Its leaves are compound, with serrated edges, and it produces white to pale pink flowers in the spring. The fruit is often used in local cuisines and has traditional medicinal uses among indigenous communities.
